newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada financial sector taxes soar.
newsitem.headline: Canada financial sector taxes soar.

text.p: Income taxes paid by Canadian financial corporations skyrocketed between 1988 and 1994, Statistics Canada said on Thursday.

In 1994, the latest year for which figures are available, financial corporations paid C$4.9 billion in corporate income taxes, an increase of more than 104 percent from the tax load of C$2.4 billion in 1988, StatsCan said.
The increase stemmed mainly from the introduction of a federal tax on capital in 1990, the federal statistics agency said.
The amount of income taxes paid by companies in non-financial sectors was relatively stagnant between 1988 and 1994, the agency said.
The financial sector accounted for one quarter of all corporate taxes paid in 1994, compared with only 14 percent in 1988.
In total, Canadian corporations paid C$20.1 billion in income taxes in 1994, surpassing the pre-recession peak of C$17.8 billion in 1989, StatsCan said.
